news.Title: [AI Summary] VIS Revenue Reaches New Highs, Expansion Ahead of Schedule; Stock Boosted by Power Management IC Outlook
news.Content:
According to reports from Liberty Times, VIS (World Advanced Integrated Circuits Corp., 5347.TWO) has seen a variety of news recently. A report on November 1, 2025, indicated that VIS's September revenue hit a 39-month high, and its third-quarter revenue also reached a nearly two-year quarterly high, exceeding expectations. September revenue reached NT$5.111 billion, a month-on-month increase of 40.98% and a year-on-year increase of 10.76%; third-quarter revenue was NT$12.35 billion, a quarter-on-quarter increase of 5.56%. Huang Huilan, Vice President and CFO of the company, stated that revenue growth was mainly due to increased wafer shipments. In addition, the construction of VIS's Singapore 12-inch fab is progressing smoothly, and the mass production schedule may be ahead of the original plan, with equipment expected to be moved in during the fourth quarter, samples produced in the second half of 2026, and mass production in the first quarter of 2027. The fab is a joint venture with NXP and is VIS's first 12-inch fab.

Liberty Times also reported that VIS's stock price surged to the limit up due to the promising outlook for power management IC foundry. Foreign institutional investors believe that power management ICs will help VIS's capacity utilization rate recover and pricing strategies remain stable. Han? (Han? Technology) is cooperating with VIS to build an 8-inch silicon carbide (SiC) production line at VIS's Second Factory in Hsinchu Science Park, with the goal of starting mass production in the second half of 2026, initially targeting industrial control and consumer products. VIS invested NT$2.48 billion last year to subscribe to Han?'s private placement shares, acquiring more than 13% of the equity.

However, U.S. President Donald Trump's chip tariff policy may pose challenges to companies such as UMC and VIS. Liberty Times quoted foreign media reports that the Trump administration's "Section 232" semiconductor-related investigation covers equipment, materials, and various products containing chips. VIS stated in response that the impact of tariffs has dulled, and the semiconductor industry is growing moderately in the second half of the year. The company expects wafer shipments in the third quarter to increase by 7% to 9% quarter-on-quarter, and the average selling price (ASP) to increase by approximately 1% to 3% quarter-on-quarter.

In addition, in the case of Sinyang Semiconductor suing iTest for trade secret infringement, the first instance ruled that iTest should compensate Sinyang Semiconductor approximately NT$41.49 million, and Sinyang Semiconductor's civil lawsuit against VIS was rejected. iTest plans to appeal.
